front: What is the Laplace Transform of the unit impulse δ(t)?
back:
$$L\{\delta(t)\} = 1$$

The transform equals 1 for all values of s (ROC: entire s-plane). This is because the impulse 'sifts' out the value of e^(-st) at t = 0.

front: What is the Laplace Transform of the unit step u(t)?
back:
$$L\{u(t)\} = \frac{1}{s}, \quad \text{ROC: Re}\{s\} > 0$$

The unit step transforms to a simple pole at the origin with ROC in the right half-plane.

front: What is the Laplace Transform of e^(at)u(t)?
back:
$$L\{e^{at}u(t)\} = \frac{1}{s-a}, \quad \text{ROC: Re}\{s\} > \text{Re}\{a\}$$

The causal exponential produces a simple pole at s = a. The ROC is to the right of this pole.

front: State the linearity property of the Laplace Transform.
back:
$$L\{\alpha_1 x_1(t) + \alpha_2 x_2(t)\} = \alpha_1 X_1(s) + \alpha_2 X_2(s)$$

The Laplace Transform is linear, allowing us to decompose complex signals and find transforms of each component separately.

front: State the time-shifting property of the Laplace Transform.
back:
$$L\{x(t - t_0)\} = e^{-st_0} X(s)$$

A delay in time corresponds to multiplication by an exponential factor in the s-domain. The ROC remains unchanged.

front: State the time-differentiation property of the Laplace Transform.
back:
$$L\left\{\frac{dx(t)}{dt}\right\} = sX(s) - x(0^-)$$

Differentiation in time becomes multiplication by s, minus the initial condition. This is key for solving differential equations.

front: What is the Region of Convergence (ROC)?
back:
The ROC is the set of all values of s for which the Laplace Transform integral converges to a finite result.

The ROC is essential for unique inverse transformation and determining system properties like stability and causality.

front: What is the ROC for a causal signal?
back:
For a causal signal (zero for t < 0), the ROC is to the **right** of the rightmost pole:

$$\text{ROC: Re}\{s\} > \sigma_1$$

where σ₁ is the real part of the rightmost pole.

front: What is the s-domain impedance of a capacitor?
back:
$$Z_C = \frac{1}{sC}$$

The capacitor impedance is inversely proportional to both frequency (s) and capacitance (C). At DC (s = 0), it becomes infinite (open circuit).

front: What is the s-domain impedance of an inductor?
back:
$$Z_L = sL$$

The inductor impedance is directly proportional to both frequency (s) and inductance (L). At DC (s = 0), it becomes zero (short circuit).

front: What is the Laplace Transform of cos(ω₀t)u(t)?
back:
$$L\{\cos(\omega_0 t)u(t)\} = \frac{s}{s^2 + \omega_0^2}, \quad \text{ROC: Re}\{s\} > 0$$

The cosine has complex conjugate poles on the jω axis at s = ±jω₀.

front: What is the Laplace Transform of sin(ω₀t)u(t)?
back:
$$L\{\sin(\omega_0 t)u(t)\} = \frac{\omega_0}{s^2 + \omega_0^2}, \quad \text{ROC: Re}\{s\} > 0$$

The sine has the same poles as cosine but a different numerator. The ω₀ factor in the numerator normalizes the response.

front: For a causal LTI system, what condition ensures stability?
back:
All poles must be in the **left half-plane** (have negative real parts).

This ensures the ROC includes the jω axis, meaning the system has a Fourier Transform and bounded output for bounded input.

front: What is the cover-up method for partial fraction expansion?
back:
For a simple pole at s = p:

$$A = (s-p)X(s)\bigg|_{s=p}$$

Multiply X(s) by (s-p), 'cover up' the (s-p) factor, and evaluate the remaining expression at s = p.

front: What is the relationship between Laplace and Fourier Transforms?
back:
The Fourier Transform is a special case of the Laplace Transform evaluated on the jω axis:

$$X(j\omega) = X(s)\bigg|_{s=j\omega}$$

This only exists when the ROC includes the jω axis.
